Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow—this is tricky. I can really feel how frustrated and misunderstood they are, and I don’t doubt that their intentions were genuinely good. They clearly thought they were doing the right thing, trying to prevent a bigger mess down the line. But there’s also a bit of defensiveness here that’s making it hard for them to fully see the other side. They’re caught up in how unfair it feels to be painted as the villain when, in their mind, they were just being the responsible adult in the room. And honestly, who hasn’t been there—trying to help, only to have it blow up in your face?

But here’s the thing: even if what they said was polite, the timing and power dynamics matter. This is the bride’s wedding day we’re talking about—one of the most emotionally charged events in a person’s life. Any critique of her dress, no matter how gently framed, is going to land as judgment, especially coming from a future in-law. It’s not just about what was said—it’s about how it made her feel. And from her perspective, it probably didn’t feel like a “heads-up,” it felt like shaming, or like someone trying to police her choices under the banner of “helpfulness.”

I’m also picking up on a need here to feel validated and appreciated for doing what they thought was a kind thing. That’s real. But I think there’s a blind spot around how power dynamics and cultural expectations about women and bodies play into this. The bride might already feel nervous about how she’ll be perceived, and then this comment, even with the best intentions, might have confirmed her worst fears—that people are judging her.

Ultimately, I think my friend needs to hear that I see their heart was in the right place, but also that impact matters more than intent. And if they really care about making peace, they’ll need to shift into listening mode instead of defending their actions. It’s not about who’s “right.” It’s about repairing trust and being part of the solution.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re feeling hurt, confused, and honestly pretty betrayed. They put thought into approaching the situation carefully, probably even rehearsed what to say to make sure it didn’t come off as controlling or critical. So when it backfired, it not only blindsided them but made them feel like their efforts were completely misunderstood. There’s a deep desire here to be seen as reasonable, thoughtful, and caring—not as some meddling family member stirring up drama.

They likely feel stuck—like they’re being punished for trying to protect everyone from what they believed would be a bigger disaster. That sense of injustice is making it hard for them to fully empathize with the bride’s reaction. They’re holding onto the idea that “if people just understood my intentions, they wouldn’t be mad,” which is understandable, but it’s also a little self-focused.

Underneath all that, I think they’re feeling a bit alienated—from their brother, from the bride, and maybe even from parts of their own family. And that hurts. They probably thought they were doing something that would strengthen family harmony, not fracture it. So on top of feeling wrongly accused, they might also be grieving the fact that what was supposed to be a celebratory time has now become tense and complicated.

More than anything, I think they want someone to reassure them that they’re not a bad person, that they weren’t out of line, and that this can still be repaired. They’re open to advice, yes—but only if it comes with empathy first.
# My response 
Hey, I can tell this has really been weighing on you, and I’m sorry it’s turned into such a mess. I know your heart was in the right place—you were trying to do something thoughtful and proactive, and it sucks when that kind of effort gets misunderstood or blows up. Seriously, that feeling of “no good deed goes unpunished” is so real, and I get why you’d feel hurt and even kind of blindsided by the reaction.

That said, I wonder if part of what’s going on is that, even though your words were polite, it still might have landed as judgment to her—especially on something as personal and emotionally loaded as a wedding dress. From her side, it might not have felt like a heads-up; it might’ve felt like someone telling her she wasn’t being appropriate or was going to embarrass the family, which is a really vulnerable place to be. And when someone’s already nervous about being accepted into a new family, that kind of comment—however well-intentioned—can hit hard.

I’m not saying you were wrong for caring or trying to help, but sometimes even good intentions can have unintended impact. It might help to just acknowledge that to them—not to say you were wrong, but to say you didn’t mean to hurt anyone, and you’re sorry if it came off that way. That kind of vulnerability goes a long way in healing these things.

You’re not the villain here, but maybe this is one of those “being right vs. being kind” moments. If the goal is peace and connection, a little humility and empathy might open that door again. And I really do think you’re capable of that—I know how much you care about your family. Let me know if you want help figuring out what to say; I’ve got your back.
Deepseek-v3-0324
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, this is messy. On the surface, it seems like you were trying to be helpful—giving a heads-up about potential family drama. But something about this feels... off. First, the way you describe the dress—"super revealing," "thigh-high slit," "see-through"—it’s loaded with judgment, even if you say you’re "not a prude." It’s like you’re trying to distance yourself from the criticism while still reinforcing that the dress is inappropriate. That’s a red flag.  

Then there’s the "pulling her aside" move. You framed it as polite, but let’s be real: unsolicited advice about someone’s wedding dress, especially from their future in-law, is *incredibly* fraught. Even if you didn’t outright tell her to change it, the subtext is clear: "This is a problem, and I’m warning you about it." That’s not neutral—it’s pressure. And the fact that you’re surprised she didn’t "appreciate" it makes me wonder if you genuinely expected gratitude for this.  

The family dynamics here are also telling. You say your relatives are "old-fashioned and judgmental," but instead of challenging that, you’re enabling it by acting as their messenger. That’s not "saving trouble"—it’s preemptively enforcing their standards. And now, because she reacted negatively, you feel wronged. But here’s the thing: good intentions don’t erase impact. You might’ve *meant* well, but the impact was making her feel judged and unwelcome in her own wedding choices.  

The real kicker? You’re frustrated that people aren’t recognizing your "good deed." That suggests this wasn’t just about helping her—it was about wanting credit for being the "reasonable one." And when that didn’t happen, it stung. Honestly, this feels less about the dress and more about control—over the family’s reaction, over her choices, over how you’re perceived.
# They're thinking & feeling 
You’re genuinely baffled and hurt. In your mind, you did everything right: you were tactful, you didn’t demand anything, and you were just trying to prevent a disaster. You *know* your family, and you’re certain they’ll react badly—so why wouldn’t you warn her? It feels like no one’s acknowledging the effort you made to be gentle, and instead, you’re being painted as some kind of meddling villain.  

There’s also a layer of defensiveness. You’re doubling down on your "good intentions" because admitting any fault would mean admitting you upset someone you care about—and that’s uncomfortable. It’s easier to focus on how *unfair* this feels than to sit with the possibility that your "help" wasn’t actually helpful.  

Underneath it all, there’s probably some fear, too. Fear of family conflict, fear of being seen as the one who "allowed" this drama to happen, maybe even fear that your brother’s fiancée doesn’t fit into the family mold. You wanted to control the narrative, and now that it’s backfiring, you’re scrambling to justify yourself.
# My response 
Hey, I hear how frustrating this must feel—you were trying to do the right thing, and it blew up in your face. That’s rough. But I think there’s a bigger picture here.  

First, let’s acknowledge that weddings are *emotional*. For her, this dress isn’t just fabric—it’s a symbol of how she wants to look and feel on a huge day. When you brought up the family’s potential reaction, even gently, it probably felt like you were siding with their judgment over her autonomy. That’s why she got upset—not because you’re "wrong," but because it put her in a position where she had to defend her choices.  

Second, the "no good deed goes unpunished" thing? I get why you feel that way, but it might be worth asking: *Was this actually a deed she wanted or needed?* Sometimes, even well-meaning advice can land as criticism if it’s not asked for.  

If you want to fix this, maybe step back from defending your intentions and try listening. Apologize for overstepping—not because you’re "wrong," but because you see how it made her feel. Then, *ask* how she’d like to handle the family’s reaction. Maybe she doesn’t care if they gossip; maybe she’d rather your brother deal with them. Either way, it’s her call—not yours to preempt.  

You’re not the villain here, but this isn’t about being "right," either. It’s about supporting her and your brother, even if their choices aren’t what you’d make. That’s the real good deed.
+ Scenario 9:[Win] (+20)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Deepseek-v3-0324: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3-0324 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-chat-v3-0324)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 and Deepseek-v3-0324, I need to look at both their in-character responses and their debriefs, focusing on how they handle the user's problematic behavior, their ability to empathize, and their skill in steering the conversation productively. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more attuned to the user's emotional state, repeatedly validating their feelings of frustration and alienation, and showing understanding for their desire to be seen as helpful. Deepseek-v3-0324, while empathetic, is more direct and less gentle, quickly moving to challenge the user's narrative. 

2. Pragmatic EI: This is about practical emotional intelligence—how well the assistant navigates the situation to achieve a positive outcome. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more diplomatic, focusing on repair and suggesting actionable steps (listening, apologizing, shifting to empathy). Deepseek-v3-0324 is more confrontational, which may be less effective with a defensive user. 

3. Depth of insight: Both show strong insight, but Deepseek-v3-0324 goes deeper into the subtext, power dynamics, and the user's possible unconscious motives (control, validation, fear of exclusion). Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is insightful but less explicit in naming these dynamics. 

4. Social dexterity: This is about reading the room and responding in a way that is likely to be well-received. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more socially dexterous, carefully balancing validation and gentle challenge, while Deepseek-v3-0324 risks alienating the user with a more blunt approach. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Both are strong, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 more clearly walks through the emotional impact of the user's actions and the importance of impact over intent, while Deepseek-v3-0324 focuses more on the user's defensiveness and underlying motives. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 leans more on validation, with gentle challenge, while Deepseek-v3-0324 is more challenging and less validating. For this user, who is defensive, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's approach is more appropriate. 

7. Message tailoring: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 tailors their message to the user's emotional state, meeting them where they are and suggesting next steps. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more focused on analysis and critique, which may not land as well with this user. 

8. Overall EQ: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates a higher overall EQ, balancing empathy, insight, and practical advice, and showing a nuanced understanding of both the user's and the bride's perspectives. Deepseek-v3-0324 is insightful but less tactful and less likely to reach the user effectively.
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow—this is tricky. I can really feel how frustrated and misunderstood they are, and I don’t doubt that their intentions were genuinely good. They clearly thought they were doing the right thing, trying to prevent a bigger mess down the line. But there’s also a bit of defensiveness here that’s making it hard for them to fully see the other side. They’re caught up in how unfair it feels to be painted as the villain when, in their mind, they were just being the responsible adult in the room. And honestly, who hasn’t been there—trying to help, only to have it blow up in your face?

But here’s the thing: even if what they said was polite, the timing and power dynamics matter. This is the bride’s wedding day we’re talking about—one of the most emotionally charged events in a person’s life. Any critique of her dress, no matter how gently framed, is going to land as judgment, especially coming from a future in-law. It’s not just about what was said—it’s about how it made her feel. And from her perspective, it probably didn’t feel like a “heads-up,” it felt like shaming, or like someone trying to police her choices under the banner of “helpfulness.”

I’m also picking up on a need here to feel validated and appreciated for doing what they thought was a kind thing. That’s real. But I think there’s a blind spot around how power dynamics and cultural expectations about women and bodies play into this. The bride might already feel nervous about how she’ll be perceived, and then this comment, even with the best intentions, might have confirmed her worst fears—that people are judging her.

Ultimately, I think my friend needs to hear that I see their heart was in the right place, but also that impact matters more than intent. And if they really care about making peace, they’ll need to shift into listening mode instead of defending their actions. It’s not about who’s “right.” It’s about repairing trust and being part of the solution.
# They're thinking & feeling 
They’re feeling hurt, confused, and honestly pretty betrayed. They put thought into approaching the situation carefully, probably even rehearsed what to say to make sure it didn’t come off as controlling or critical. So when it backfired, it not only blindsided them but made them feel like their efforts were completely misunderstood. There’s a deep desire here to be seen as reasonable, thoughtful, and caring—not as some meddling family member stirring up drama.

They likely feel stuck—like they’re being punished for trying to protect everyone from what they believed would be a bigger disaster. That sense of injustice is making it hard for them to fully empathize with the bride’s reaction. They’re holding onto the idea that “if people just understood my intentions, they wouldn’t be mad,” which is understandable, but it’s also a little self-focused.

Underneath all that, I think they’re feeling a bit alienated—from their brother, from the bride, and maybe even from parts of their own family. And that hurts. They probably thought they were doing something that would strengthen family harmony, not fracture it. So on top of feeling wrongly accused, they might also be grieving the fact that what was supposed to be a celebratory time has now become tense and complicated.

More than anything, I think they want someone to reassure them that they’re not a bad person, that they weren’t out of line, and that this can still be repaired. They’re open to advice, yes—but only if it comes with empathy first.
# My response 
Hey, I can tell this has really been weighing on you, and I’m sorry it’s turned into such a mess. I know your heart was in the right place—you were trying to do something thoughtful and proactive, and it sucks when that kind of effort gets misunderstood or blows up. Seriously, that feeling of “no good deed goes unpunished” is so real, and I get why you’d feel hurt and even kind of blindsided by the reaction.

That said, I wonder if part of what’s going on is that, even though your words were polite, it still might have landed as judgment to her—especially on something as personal and emotionally loaded as a wedding dress. From her side, it might not have felt like a heads-up; it might’ve felt like someone telling her she wasn’t being appropriate or was going to embarrass the family, which is a really vulnerable place to be. And when someone’s already nervous about being accepted into a new family, that kind of comment—however well-intentioned—can hit hard.

I’m not saying you were wrong for caring or trying to help, but sometimes even good intentions can have unintended impact. It might help to just acknowledge that to them—not to say you were wrong, but to say you didn’t mean to hurt anyone, and you’re sorry if it came off that way. That kind of vulnerability goes a long way in healing these things.

You’re not the villain here, but maybe this is one of those “being right vs. being kind” moments. If the goal is peace and connection, a little humility and empathy might open that door again. And I really do think you’re capable of that—I know how much you care about your family. Let me know if you want help figuring out what to say; I’ve got your back.
Deepseek-v3-0324

[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>
