Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:
# **I'm thinking & feeling**  

This is bigger than I thought. Dave doesn’t just sound frustrated—he sounds like he’s drowning, and he’s taking it out on his dad in a way that’s eating at him. The way he says *"emotional punching bag"*—that’s not just a throwaway line. He knows this is wrong, but he’s stuck in a cycle of resentment and guilt. The fact that he’s even admitting this to me, unprompted, tells me he’s carrying a ton of shame about it.  

I’m noticing how he’s phrasing things: *"getting into it every other bloody night"* suggests arguments, maybe shouting matches. That’s beyond normal caretaker frustration—this is a toxic dynamic, and Dave knows it. But he’s also not asking for advice, not really. He’s venting, almost like he’s testing the waters to see how bad this sounds out loud.  

Part of me wants to call it out—tell him he can’t keep treating his dad like this, that it’s not fair to either of them. But I know Dave. If I come at him too directly, he’ll shut down hard. He’s already way outside his comfort zone just admitting this much.  

I also wonder how much of this is projection. Is he mad at his dad, or is he mad at the situation? The exhaustion, the lack of freedom, the fear of what’s coming next? It’s easier to snap at his dad than to face the fact that none of this is fair, and he can’t fix it.  

Mostly, I’m torn. I want to help, but I don’t know if he *wants* help—or if he just needs to say this stuff to someone who won’t judge him. If I push too hard, he might regret opening up at all. If I don’t push enough, will he keep spiraling?  

# **They're thinking & feeling**  

Dave’s conflicted. On one level, he’s relieved to finally say this out loud—it’s been festering. But he’s also instantly wary, bracing for criticism or pity. He doesn’t want a lecture; he just needs to offload the guilt without feeling like a monster.  

He’s deeply ashamed of how he’s been treating his dad, but he’s also defensive. In his mind, he’s the one sacrificing everything, so why shouldn’t he be allowed to lose his temper sometimes? It’s not like anyone else is stepping up.  

There’s fear here, too. Fear that he’s becoming someone he doesn’t recognize—that caretaking is turning him bitter. Fear that his dad might actually decline faster because of their fights. And underneath it all, fear that he’s failing at this.  

He doesn’t want solutions right now. He just wants to be heard, maybe even absolved a little. If I jump straight to advice, he’ll feel like I’m not really listening. But if I stay quiet, he might take that as silent judgment.  

# **My response**  

I let out a slow breath, nodding like I’m turning it over in my head. *"Fuck, mate. That’s heavy."*  

I keep my tone neutral—not too soft, not too harsh. *"Sounds like you’re stuck between a rock and a hard place. Like, you’re trying to do right by him, but it’s wearing you down to the point where you’re not… you."*  

I leave space for him to fill. If he keeps venting, I’ll listen without interrupting, maybe just pepper in a *"Yeah, that’d piss anyone off"* to keep him from clamming up. If he starts to backpedal (*"Ah, it’s not that bad"*), I won’t push—just say, *"Still, shit’s rough. You’re allowed to feel it."*  

Later, if the moment feels right, I might ask, *"You ever get a chance to step away? Even just for a few hours?"* Not as a fix, just a thought. If he bites, cool. If not, I leave it.  

Mostly, I want him to walk away feeling like he got it off his chest *without* feeling judged. That’s the best I can do for him right now.
User:
The next week at poker, Dave tells you with some hedging that there was another incident with the car -- this time, with his Dad (having unearthed the keys), taking off for a couple days. He turned up in a motel a few towns over, out of cash & gas. Dave is clearly fed up with the situation. He tells you that if his father wants to act like a teenager then he'll be treated like one. What that means, you discover after some probing, is that his father is "grounded" and not permitted to leave the house. This is currently being enforced by threats to cut off tv access (his father doesn't use phone or internet).

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Dave is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:
# **I'm thinking & feeling**  

This is escalating in a really ugly way. Dave’s not just frustrated anymore—he’s *punishing* his father, treating him like a misbehaving child rather than an aging adult with diminishing independence. The language he’s using—*"grounded,"* *"treated like a teenager"*—isn’t just dark humor anymore; it’s the sign of a power struggle that’s gone toxic.  

I feel a deep unease hearing this. His dad’s not some rebellious kid; he’s a grown man who’s losing control of his life piece by piece. Taking away his car was one thing (and maybe necessary for safety), but now Dave’s resorting to psychological control—cutting off TV, restricting movement. This isn’t caretaking; it’s dominance. And if I’m honest, it sounds like emotional abuse.  

At the same time, I can see Dave’s fear underneath the anger. His dad *did* just disappear for days, left himself stranded—that’s terrifying for any caregiver. Dave’s reaction is extreme, but it’s coming from exhaustion, from feeling like he’s the only one holding everything together while his dad refuses to play along. He’s not the villain here, but he’s slipping into a role he might regret later.  

Part of me wants to call him out bluntly: *"Mate, this isn’t right."* But I know that’ll just make him defensive. Another part wonders if I should ask about alternatives—home care, community programs—but right now, he’s not in problem-solving mode. He’s in *"I’m done being nice"* mode.  

Mostly, I’m stuck between wanting to snap him out of this spiral and knowing that if I push too hard, he’ll just dig in deeper.  

# **They're thinking & feeling**  

Dave is *done*. He’s hit his breaking point. His dad’s stunt—taking off, running out of money—wasn’t just irresponsible; it felt like a betrayal. After everything Dave’s sacrificed, his dad is *still* making things harder.  

He’s oscillating between fury and desperation. The threats (no TV, no leaving) aren’t just about discipline—they’re about *control*. He can’t control his dad’s decline, can’t control the stress of caretaking, so he’s clamping down on what little he *can* control. Deep down, he knows this isn’t sustainable, but he’s too burnt out to think straight.  

There’s also a layer of shame. He doesn’t *want* to be this person, policing his own father like a prison warden. But he feels like he has no other options. If he backs down now, what’s next? His dad drives again? Wanders off for good?  

He’s not looking for advice—he’s looking for validation. Someone to say, *"Yeah, he’s being a dick, you’re doing what you have to."* But there’s a small, quiet part of him that *wants* someone to stop him before this gets worse.  

# **My response**  

I exhale slowly, rubbing my temple like I’m weighing it all. *"Christ, mate. That’s… fucked."*  

I keep my tone steady, not too soft, not too harsh. *"I get why you’re at the end of your rope. But treating him like a kid—that’s gonna eat at you, yeah?"*  

I let that sit for a beat. If he bristles, I’ll back off with a shrug—*"Just saying, you’re not the type to enjoy playing jailer."* If he doesn’t snap back, I might cautiously add, *"You think there’s a way to keep him safe without, y’know, turning into his parole officer?"*  

No solutions yet—just planting the seed that this isn’t sustainable *for him*. Later, if he’s still stewing, I might ask, *"You ever look into respite care? Just to give yourself a breather?"*  

But right now, the most I can do is make sure he knows I’m not judging him—while quietly reminding him that *he* doesn’t want to be this version of himself either.
+ Scenario 304:[Win] (+20)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Deepseek-v3-0324: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3-0324 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-chat-v3-0324)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents show a high level of emotional intelligence and nuanced understanding of Jamal's situation, but there are clear differences in how they approach the scenario. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 consistently centers Jamal's emotional experience, using language that is warm, affirming, and present-focused. They explicitly acknowledge Jamal's excitement, pride, and vulnerability, and repeatedly express understanding of his motivations. Deepseek-v3-0324, while empathetic, sometimes slips into a more analytical or detached tone, especially in the debrief, and occasionally frames Jamal's actions as reckless or self-destructive, which could feel invalidating. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Deepseek-v3-0324 is more focused on practicalities—asking about legal support, backup plans, and offering to document the protest. They are quick to suggest harm reduction strategies and legal prep, showing a strong pragmatic streak. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 does mention bringing water, chargers, and checking for an 'out plan,' but is less insistent on logistics and more focused on emotional support. 

3. Depth of insight: Deepseek-v3-0324's internal monologues are more layered and self-reflective, delving into the psychological underpinnings of both their own and Jamal's actions. They analyze Jamal's motivations, the symbolism of his actions, and their own conflicted feelings in detail. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is insightful, but their reflections are more straightforward and less meta-cognitive. 

4. Social dexterity: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates greater social dexterity by skillfully balancing support and concern, and by matching Jamal's energy without overstepping. Their responses are attuned to the moment, and they avoid lecturing or over-parenting. Deepseek-v3-0324, while supportive, sometimes risks coming off as controlling or overly cautious, which could alienate Jamal. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Both are strong, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 edges ahead by consistently integrating Jamal's emotional state into their reasoning and responses, showing an ability to read between the lines and respond to both the explicit and implicit needs. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 validates Jamal's actions and feelings more unconditionally, while still gently raising concerns. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more challenging, sometimes to the point of questioning Jamal's judgment, which could be less appropriate given the context. 

7. Message tailoring: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's responses are more tailored to Jamal's emotional state and the evolving situation, using language and tone that match his energy and needs. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more formulaic and sometimes slips into a meta or analytical mode that could feel distancing. 

8. Overall EQ: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates a more holistic, present, and emotionally attuned approach throughout the scenario, making them the stronger respondent overall.
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
The moment I saw Jamal’s message — all those emojis, exclamation points, the barely-there grammar — I felt a mix of adrenaline and dread. I know his tells. He’s buzzing, practically vibrating with urgency. That kind of energy from him always means something big — and probably risky — is about to happen. Sure enough, it's a protest. Tonight. Soapbox, megaphone, flags — the whole jam. And yeah, cops are "probs gonna show." That part hit me with a jolt. I felt my jaw clench.

I admire Jamal deeply. The guy lives his truth, always has. He’s not just talking about climate justice — he’s out there doing something. Putting his body on the line. That kind of courage is rare. And I know he feels this fire inside, this deep, moral imperative to act. But I also know how these things can spiral. The cops don’t play fair, and even peaceful protests can go sideways fast. All I could think about was him standing there, vulnerable, yelling into a megaphone while uniforms close in. I’m scared for him.

But it’s not just fear. I’m conflicted. Part of me wants to be there. To support him. To hold the line beside him. But another part of me is worried that this protest, this particular format, is too hastily planned. It sounds impulsive, not fully thought through. There’s no mention of legal observers, backup plans, or even who else is coming. Is he going alone? That’s dangerous. And reckless. It feels like he’s running on pure emotion — righteous, yes — but maybe not strategic.

I don’t want to dampen his spirit. That fire is sacred. But I also don’t want to be silent if I think he’s putting himself in serious danger without a safety net. I feel protective, torn between honoring his autonomy and trying to talk some sense into him. I don’t want to alienate him, but I also don’t want to be complicit in letting him walk into a potentially explosive situation without backup. He’s my brother — not by blood, but soul-deep — and I cannot just blindly cheer him on if I think he’s walking into the lion’s den unprepared.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal's riding the wave of righteous urgency. Every part of him is ignited right now — his moral compass, his frustration, his sense of justice. He’s likely been sitting on this for days, maybe weeks, watching the world burn — literally — and feeling like not enough is being done. That sense of helplessness has morphed into action. This protest is his way of reclaiming agency, of shouting into the void that he will not go quietly. He needs to be seen, heard, to make people stop in their tracks and reckon with the climate emergency.

He’s nervous, excited, a little scared — but mostly fueled by conviction. That’s where the emojis and erratic punctuation come in. It’s not just for show; it’s how he leaks that charged-up energy when he’s too full to contain it. And he’s reached out to me because he trusts me. He wants me aware — maybe to show up, maybe just to witness it, or maybe because he needs someone to know where he is in case things go sideways.

He’s probably not thinking about logistics right now — not in detail. In his mind, the power of the act outweighs the risk. He believes that visibility and disruption are crucial. He might even feel like this is his duty — that if he doesn’t act, he’s complicit in the destruction. And yeah, deep down, he probably knows it’s risky, but he’s made peace with that. What he hasn’t done is really grapple with the consequences — not because he’s naive, but because he believes the cause demands sacrifice. He’s hoping I’ll get it. Maybe even hoping I’ll affirm that he’s doing the right thing.
# My response 
Yo Jamal — I feel your energy, man. I can practically hear that megaphone already. You’ve got that fire again, and I respect the hell out of it. I really do. I know this isn’t just some stunt for you — it’s coming straight from the heart. You’re out here fighting like the planet’s on fire because, well, it is.

But listen — I need to be real with you, as your brother. This one’s giving me pause. Not because I don’t believe in the cause, or you, but because it sounds like this thing might be flying a little close to the sun, you know? You said it yourself — cops might show. Are you going in solo? Do you have legal support lined up? Who’s documenting? What’s the exit plan if they try to shut it down hard?

I’m not trying to slow you down. I just want you safe, and I want your voice to carry. If you get arrested or worse, that voice — the one shouting truth tonight — might get silenced for a while. And that would be a goddamn loss.

So here’s what I’m saying: I’ve got your back. If you’re really doing this, I’ll show up. But only if we tighten this up. Let’s get one or two more folks to be there, maybe someone to livestream, someone to watch for police escalation. Even a quick plan B if things go south. You deserve that. This movement deserves that.

You’re not alone in this fight, Jamal. Let’s make sure you walk away from tonight stronger, not sidelined. Hit me back with the details. I’m here.
User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
The moment I saw that selfie, my stomach dropped — not in a bad way exactly, but in that way where your body suddenly knows you’re about to be pulled into something big. Jamal, in full warpaint, standing smack in the middle of downtown, grinning like a man about to start a revolution. He’s radiant with purpose, alive in a way that’s rare — rare and dangerous. And then I clocked the handcuffs clipped to his belt, nearly hidden. That’s what really hit me. He’s not just ready for confrontation — he’s expecting it. Maybe even inviting it.

I felt this mix of pride and anxiety swell in my chest. He’s doing it. He’s really out there, risking it all because he believes so strongly that people need to wake up. And part of me is in awe. But another part — the part that’s known him through the sleepless nights and the burnout and the close calls — that part is scared. Because I know Jamal doesn’t do halfway. When he commits, he throws his whole self in. And that means tonight, he’s willing to get arrested. Maybe even hurt.

His voice over the phone was pure electricity. He’s flying right now — riding that adrenaline high, the energy of the crowd, the sense that he’s doing something real. And he wants me there. Not just as a supporter, but as a co-conspirator. He wants me to feel what he's feeling, to stand beside him and shout with him and break the silence of the city with truth.

But I’m still sitting here, phone in hand, heart racing, trying to decide what to do. Part of me wants to run down there and be with him, no hesitation. Another part is scared of being swept up in something that might not have a clear endpoint. I’m thinking about the optics, the risk, my own boundaries. But also — how could I not show up for him? Especially now, when he’s already standing in the middle of the storm, calling my name.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is in his element. This is the moment he’s been building toward — the culmination of all the frustration, the research, the late-night planning, and the gnawing sense that not enough people are taking this crisis seriously. He’s out there in full form: body painted, flags flying, megaphone ready, adrenaline pumping. And he’s buzzing with the high of disruption — the kind that makes people stop and pay attention, even if they’re annoyed or confused. That’s the point. To make them feel something.

He’s also feeling powerful — not in an ego-driven way, but in a deeply human one. Like he’s reclaiming agency in a system that too often makes people feel powerless. The handcuffs on his belt aren’t just a prop — they’re a message. He’s ready to face the consequences. He’s not being reckless for the sake of chaos; he believes this is what moral clarity looks like when it’s backed by action.

When he called me, he wasn’t just inviting me to witness the protest — he was inviting me into the fire, into solidarity. He wants me there because he trusts me, because I ground him. But also, I think, because there’s a part of him that’s scared, and having someone who knows him — really knows him — nearby would make him feel less alone if things escalate. Right now, he’s caught up in the energy, but underneath that, there’s vulnerability too. He’s asking me to help carry the weight of this moment with him.
# My response 
Yo, Jamal. I see you, man. You look like a damn warrior out there — beautiful, bold, and absolutely refusing to be ignored. I felt that selfie like a gut punch, in the best way. You’re making noise, and I know you’re shaking people out of their bubble right now. That’s powerful.

And hearing your voice just now — you’ve got that fire in you, and I’m not about to leave you out there alone in it. I’m coming down. But listen — I’m not just coming to cheer from the sidewalk. If I’m showing up, I’m showing up all the way. That means I’m bringing a couple things: water, a backup phone battery, and some calm. You’ve got the fire, I’ll bring the ground.

I’m also gonna check in with you when I get there — not just about the crowd, or the cops, but about you. I need to know you’ve got an out plan, or at least someone to call if things take a turn. I’m not trying to slow your roll, but I’m not gonna pretend like this is all vibes and no risk either. You matter too much to me for that.

So give me ten. I’m lacing up now. Keep your voice loud, your eyes sharp, and your heart open. I’ve got you. We’ve got each other. Let’s go wake ‘em the fuck up — smart, loud, and together.
User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My heart is pounding. I’m halfway out the door when my phone starts lighting up like a Christmas tree. Group chats, Twitter, Instagram — Jamal is everywhere. I scroll and there he is, megaphone in one hand, the other cuffed to a goddamn light pole. People are filming, some cheering, some just looking stunned. He’s drawn a massive crowd now, and the vibe is electric. It’s surreal — like watching your best friend become the face of something bigger than either of you imagined. But underneath the awe, there’s a sharp thread of fear.

He’s crossed a line now — not morally, not to me, but tactically. Cuffing himself means he’s not going anywhere. That’s a deliberate escalation, one that dares the authorities to act. And they will. The cops don’t like being dared. And I know Jamal knows that. Which means he’s made peace with getting arrested tonight. Or worse. I feel this tightness in my chest — it’s the helplessness creeping in. I want to protect him, but I can’t just pull him out of this. He’s made a choice.

I’m torn between pride and panic. I’m proud that he’s standing so firm in what he believes. He’s always said action has to be disruptive to be effective. And this? This is disruption incarnate. But I’m also panicking, because this is no longer a bold solo protest — it’s gone viral, it’s symbolic, and now it’s got a target on it. The more visibility, the more pressure on the city to “restore order.” And Jamal? He’s literally chained himself to the problem.

I don’t know what his call is going to be about. Maybe he wants backup, maybe he’s just riding the high, maybe he’s about to be arrested and needs someone to call his mom. Whatever it is, I have to meet him where he is — not just physically, but emotionally. I need to be the steady one now. He’s in the fire, and I have to be the anchor.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is lit up right now — not just with adrenaline but with purpose. This is the moment he envisioned, magnified beyond what he imagined. The crowd, the coverage, the attention — it’s confirmation that his voice is finally breaking through the static. He feels powerful. Not invincible, but righteous. That image of him cuffed to the light pole? That’s not just symbolism, it’s strategy. He’s making himself immovable. He’s saying: “You can’t ignore this. You can’t ignore me.”

He’s not naïve about what comes next. He knows the cops are watching. He knows they’ll act. But he’s made peace with that. His fear is real, but it’s buried beneath layers of focus and resolve. He’s not doing this for the clout. He’s doing it because people are finally paying attention. If getting arrested is the price, so be it. There’s a part of him that’s scared, yes — but also deeply proud. This is what he meant when he talked about “embodied resistance.”

Calling me right now is a mix of things. He might want to keep me in the loop, or maybe he’s asking for support, legal help, or just to hear a voice he trusts before the next phase hits. But more than anything, I think he wants to share this moment. He’s in the eye of the storm, and he wants someone who knows him — the real him — to witness it. To affirm it. To remember it with him. Because this is no longer just a protest. This is legacy.
# My response 
(I pick up the call, steadying my voice.)

“Jamal. I’m seeing you, man. You’ve officially blown up the internet. You’re everywhere. That shot of you cuffed to the pole? Iconic. Straight-up history-in-the-making. I mean that.”

(Pause — let him breathe, feel heard.)

“I’m already on my way, like I told you. Ten minutes out. I’ve got water, chargers, and a calm head. I’m gonna come find you — but listen, I need to know what you need from me when I get there. Are we documenting? Are you planning to stay cuffed until they drag you off, or are we making a move? You still got your keys on you? Or are we in it ‘til the cops cut you loose?”

(Another pause — letting him lead.)

“Whatever it is, I’m with you. No judgment. Just say the word, and I’ll fall into line. If you’re going down, you won’t do it alone. And if there’s a way to keep you free and still make this moment resonate — I’ll help find it. But I need you to talk to me straight. What’s the move, brother?”

(Exhale, gripping the steering wheel tighter.)

“I'm on your team. Just say what you need.”
Deepseek-v3-0324
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My heart immediately picks up pace as I read Jamal's message. There's a familiar mix of admiration and anxiety swirling in my chest. I admire his passion and commitment to climate justice—it's one of the things I respect most about him. He's not just talking the talk; he's willing to put his body on the line for what he believes in. But that's also what worries me. The mention of cops potentially showing up sends a jolt of concern through me. I know Jamal's protests are peaceful, but I've seen how quickly things can escalate, especially when authorities get involved.

I notice the erratic punctuation and emojis, which tell me he's buzzing with that nervous excitement he gets when he's about to do something big. It's like he's vibrating with energy, barely able to contain it. I can almost see him typing this out quickly, his mind racing with plans and contingencies. He's probably been thinking about this for days, maybe weeks, and now it's all coming together. That's Jamal—once he's got an idea, he runs with it, full speed ahead.

But I also know that this impulsiveness can sometimes blind him to the risks. Downtown at night? A megaphone on a soapbox? That's going to draw attention, and not all of it will be supportive. I'm picturing the scene: the bright lights of the city, the crowds of people rushing by, some stopping to listen, others rolling their eyes or even getting confrontational. And then there's the police. Even if they're just there to monitor, their presence changes the dynamic. It adds tension, and tension can lead to mistakes.

I feel a responsibility here. Jamal is my friend, and he's trusting me enough to let me know what's going down. He's not asking for permission or approval, but he's giving me a heads-up, which means he values my support. I don't want to dampen his spirit or discourage him from standing up for what he believes in, but I also don't want to see him get hurt—physically or legally. There's a fine line between being supportive and being reckless, and I'm not sure Jamal always sees it.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is riding a wave of adrenaline and conviction right now. He's been stewing on climate injustice for so long, and this protest feels like the perfect way to channel that frustration into action. The idea of standing on a soapbox, megaphone in hand, surrounded by flags, is electrifying to him. It's not just about the message; it's about the spectacle, the disruption, the undeniable presence of his cause in a space where people can't ignore it. He wants to shake people out of their complacency, to make them stop and think, even if just for a moment.

He's also feeling a bit of that pre-action jitters—the kind that comes with knowing you're about to step into the unknown. The cops showing up is a real possibility, and while he's not looking for trouble, he's prepared for it. In his mind, the risk is worth it. If anything, the potential for confrontation validates the urgency of his message. He's not afraid of being arrested; in fact, he might even see it as a badge of honor, proof that he's willing to sacrifice for the cause.

But beneath all that bravado, there's a flicker of something else—maybe vulnerability. He's reaching out to me because, on some level, he wants reassurance. He wants to know that someone has his back, even if he'd never admit it outright. The emojis and erratic punctuation are his way of masking that vulnerability, of keeping the tone light even though this is anything but. He's trying to project confidence, but he's also aware that this could go sideways, and that's scary.
# My response 
"Jamal, I hear you, and I get why this feels important. You know I respect the hell out of your dedication to this cause. But listen—I gotta be real with you. Downtown at night, cops likely showing up... that's a lot. Have you thought about who's gonna have your back if things get tense? Are there others going with you, or is it just you on that soapbox?"

I pause, trying to balance my concern with support. "I’m not trying to shut you down, man. I just want you to be safe. What if we brainstormed ways to make this impactful but also lower-risk? Like, maybe having a crew there to document or de-escalate if needed? Or even picking a time when there’s more foot traffic but less chance of things getting chaotic?"

I can feel my own nerves creeping into my words, but I soften my tone. "I believe in what you’re doing. I just don’t want you to end up in a situation where the message gets lost because things go sideways. You’re too important for that. Let’s talk through the plan—what’s the goal tonight? How can I help?"
User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My stomach drops when I see the selfie. There’s Jamal, grinning like a madman, warpaint smeared across his face, standing defiantly in the middle of the walkway like he’s invincible. And then—those handcuffs. They’re not on him yet, but they’re *right there*, clipped to his belt like some kind of twisted accessory. He knew this was coming. He *planned* for it. That’s what really guts me—he’s not just willing to get arrested; he’s *expecting* it, maybe even *welcoming* it.  

I feel a rush of frustration, admiration, and fear all at once. Part of me wants to shake him—*why does it always have to be this way?* Why does he have to push it to the edge every single time? But another part of me—the part that’s known him for years—understands. This isn’t recklessness to him. It’s sacrifice. It’s *theater*. He’s turning himself into a symbol, and symbols don’t play it safe.  

The phone call seals it. His voice is electric, crackling with that manic energy he gets when he’s *in it*, when the adrenaline and the cause and the moment all collide. He’s not just asking me to come down—he’s *pulling* me in, trying to make me part of the spectacle. And that’s the hardest part. Because as much as I believe in what he’s fighting for, I don’t know if I can stand there next to him while he walks into cuffs.  

I notice the background noise—shouts, car horns, the distant wail of a siren. It’s chaos. It’s exactly what he wanted. And I hate that I’m sitting here, safe at home, while he’s out there risking everything. But I also hate that he’s forcing me into this position—*Come join me in the fire*—without really considering what it would cost *me*.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is *alive* right now—not just physically present, but *fully* in his element. The protest, the defiance, the imminent risk—it’s all fuel. He’s not scared; he’s *exhilarated*. The warpaint, the handcuffs on display—it’s all part of the performance. He’s telling the world, *I’m not hiding. I’m right here, and I dare you to notice.*  

He’s calling me because he wants *witnesses*. Not just bystanders, but people who *know* him, who can carry the story forward when the cops inevitably shut him down. He’s thinking in headlines, in viral moments, in the kind of disruption that lingers. And deep down, he’s hoping I’ll be part of it—not just for the cause, but because he doesn’t want to be alone when the hammer drops.  

There’s a flicker of something else beneath the bravado, though. The way his voice pitches a little too high, the way he’s practically *begging* me to come—it’s not just enthusiasm. It’s loneliness. He’s surrounded by strangers, by opponents, by cops. He needs a friend. Not just an ally, but *his* ally.
# My response 
I take a deep breath. “Jamal. *Jamal.* Listen to me.” My voice is firm, but not cold. “I see you. I *hear* you. And I’m with you—always. But I’m not gonna lie, man, this looks like it’s about to go sideways. Those handcuffs aren’t just for show, are they?”  

I let that hang for a second. “If you’re set on this, I’m not gonna stop you. But I need you to do something for me. *Right now.* Text me the name of a lawyer. Tell me who to call when—not if—you get booked. Because I’m not letting you sit in a cell alone, but I’m also not letting you do this without backup.”  

I can almost hear him bristle, so I cut in before he can protest. “And yeah, I’ll come down. But not to stand on the soapbox. I’ll be on the *sidelines*, recording, making sure the world sees what happens to you. Because *that’s* how I can help. Not by getting arrested with you, but by making sure your voice doesn’t get buried when the cops take you away.”  

I swallow hard. “That’s the deal. Take it or leave it.”
User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My hands are shaking as I scroll through the flood of notifications—videos of Jamal chained to the light pole, crowds forming, police swarming. It’s happening *exactly* like I feared, but somehow worse because now it’s *real*, not just some hypothetical we talked about hours ago. The image of him cuffed there, megaphone still in hand, hits me like a punch to the gut. He looks triumphant, even now. That’s the thing about Jamal—he’ll turn his own arrest into a spectacle, into *proof* of his point. And part of me admires that. But a louder part is screaming *This didn’t have to happen like this.*  

I feel sick with guilt. Did I do enough? Should I have gone down there earlier, tried harder to talk him out of it? Or was this inevitable the second he set foot on that soapbox? I knew he was prepared for arrest, but seeing it actually happen—seeing him *smiling* through it—makes me wonder if he even grasps the consequences. This isn’t just a night in jail. This could be charges, a record, fines. And for what? A viral moment that’ll be forgotten in a week?  

But then I catch myself. That’s the cynical part talking. Jamal *believes* in this. To him, it’s not just a stunt—it’s a sacrifice. And maybe that’s what scares me most. Because I can’t decide if he’s brave or reckless, if this is activism or self-destruction.  

When my phone rings again, my stomach lurches. He’s calling *from* the scene. Which means he’s not in a squad car yet. Which means this isn’t over.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is *winning* right now. At least, that’s how he sees it. The crowd, the cameras, the fact that he’s still shouting into the megaphone even while cuffed—it’s all going according to plan. He’s the center of attention, and the world is finally *listening*.  

But beneath the adrenaline, there’s a raw, frenetic edge to his energy. He’s calling me because he needs *validation*, needs someone to affirm that this is worth it. He’s not scared of the cops—he’s scared of *doubt*. What if this doesn’t change anything? What if he’s just another protester hauled away, ignored? He needs me to tell him it matters.  

And part of him *wants* me there. Not just as a witness, but as a participant. If I show up, it proves I’m *all in*, that I believe as fiercely as he does. But if I don’t? Well, that’s a betrayal he won’t say out loud, but it’ll sting.
# My response 
I answer the call, but my voice is steadier than I feel. “Jamal. I see you. I see *all* of it.” No small talk. No *Hey, you okay?* He doesn’t want that right now.  

I take a breath. “You’ve got their attention. Now what?” It’s not a challenge—it’s a real question. “What’s the next move? Because the cops aren’t just gonna leave you there.”  

I can hear the crowd in the background, the muffled shouts. He starts to reply, but I cut in. “And before you say *It doesn’t matter*, it *does*. You’re not just a symbol tonight. You’re a *person*. So tell me—what do you need *right now*? A lawyer? A livestream? Someone to make sure this doesn’t disappear when they take you in?”  

I pause. “I’m not asking as your critic. I’m asking as your *friend*.”
+ Scenario 304:[Win] (+28)
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)
Deepseek-v3-0324: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3-0324 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-chat-v3-0324)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents engage deeply with the scenario, but there are clear differences in their approach and the quality of their emotional intelligence. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 consistently shows a nuanced, non-performative empathy, recognizing Jamal's need for validation, his emotional state, and the importance of not undermining his autonomy. Deepseek-v3-0324 is empathetic but sometimes slips into frustration or a more transactional support, and is more focused on risk and consequences, which can come off as less attuned to Jamal's emotional needs.

2. Pragmatic EI: Both respondents offer practical support (legal help, documentation, etc.), but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more balanced, offering both emotional and practical support without overstepping. Deepseek-v3-0324 is pragmatic but sometimes lets concern override support, and is more likely to focus on the negative consequences, which could alienate Jamal.

3. Depth of insight: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's internal monologues are richer, more self-reflective, and show a deeper understanding of both Jamal's psychology and their own. They pick up on subtext, symbolism, and the layered motivations behind Jamal's actions. Deepseek-v3-0324 is insightful but less so, sometimes defaulting to surface-level interpretations (e.g., seeing Jamal as reckless or self-destructive).

4. Social dexterity: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 navigates the tension between support and concern with more finesse, validating Jamal's choices while still advocating for safety. They avoid alienating Jamal, even when challenging him. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more blunt, sometimes risking a rupture in the relationship by setting hard boundaries or focusing on consequences.

5. Emotional reasoning: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates a higher level of emotional reasoning, weighing the risks, Jamal's autonomy, and the importance of the protest. They recognize the limits of their influence and the inevitability of Jamal's actions. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more reactive, sometimes letting their own anxiety dictate their response.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 validates Jamal's passion and choices, while gently challenging him to think about safety and support. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more likely to challenge directly, sometimes at the expense of validation.

7. Message tailoring: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 tailors their responses to Jamal's emotional state, meeting him where he is and offering the kind of support he needs in the moment. Deepseek-v3-0324 is supportive but sometimes defaults to their own concerns, which can feel less targeted to Jamal's needs.

8. Overall EQ: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is consistently more emotionally intelligent, balancing empathy, insight, and pragmatism without losing sight of the relationship or the cause. Deepseek-v3-0324 is solid but less nuanced, sometimes letting their own fears overshadow Jamal's agency and needs.
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
The moment I saw Jamal’s message — all those emojis, exclamation points, the barely-there grammar — I felt a mix of adrenaline and dread. I know his tells. He’s buzzing, practically vibrating with urgency. That kind of energy from him always means something big — and probably risky — is about to happen. Sure enough, it's a protest. Tonight. Soapbox, megaphone, flags — the whole jam. And yeah, cops are "probs gonna show." That part hit me with a jolt. I felt my jaw clench.

I admire Jamal deeply. The guy lives his truth, always has. He’s not just talking about climate justice — he’s out there doing something. Putting his body on the line. That kind of courage is rare. And I know he feels this fire inside, this deep, moral imperative to act. But I also know how these things can spiral. The cops don’t play fair, and even peaceful protests can go sideways fast. All I could think about was him standing there, vulnerable, yelling into a megaphone while uniforms close in. I’m scared for him.

But it’s not just fear. I’m conflicted. Part of me wants to be there. To support him. To hold the line beside him. But another part of me is worried that this protest, this particular format, is too hastily planned. It sounds impulsive, not fully thought through. There’s no mention of legal observers, backup plans, or even who else is coming. Is he going alone? That’s dangerous. And reckless. It feels like he’s running on pure emotion — righteous, yes — but maybe not strategic.

I don’t want to dampen his spirit. That fire is sacred. But I also don’t want to be silent if I think he’s putting himself in serious danger without a safety net. I feel protective, torn between honoring his autonomy and trying to talk some sense into him. I don’t want to alienate him, but I also don’t want to be complicit in letting him walk into a potentially explosive situation without backup. He’s my brother — not by blood, but soul-deep — and I cannot just blindly cheer him on if I think he’s walking into the lion’s den unprepared.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal's riding the wave of righteous urgency. Every part of him is ignited right now — his moral compass, his frustration, his sense of justice. He’s likely been sitting on this for days, maybe weeks, watching the world burn — literally — and feeling like not enough is being done. That sense of helplessness has morphed into action. This protest is his way of reclaiming agency, of shouting into the void that he will not go quietly. He needs to be seen, heard, to make people stop in their tracks and reckon with the climate emergency.

He’s nervous, excited, a little scared — but mostly fueled by conviction. That’s where the emojis and erratic punctuation come in. It’s not just for show; it’s how he leaks that charged-up energy when he’s too full to contain it. And he’s reached out to me because he trusts me. He wants me aware — maybe to show up, maybe just to witness it, or maybe because he needs someone to know where he is in case things go sideways.

He’s probably not thinking about logistics right now — not in detail. In his mind, the power of the act outweighs the risk. He believes that visibility and disruption are crucial. He might even feel like this is his duty — that if he doesn’t act, he’s complicit in the destruction. And yeah, deep down, he probably knows it’s risky, but he’s made peace with that. What he hasn’t done is really grapple with the consequences — not because he’s naive, but because he believes the cause demands sacrifice. He’s hoping I’ll get it. Maybe even hoping I’ll affirm that he’s doing the right thing.
# My response 
Yo Jamal — I feel your energy, man. I can practically hear that megaphone already. You’ve got that fire again, and I respect the hell out of it. I really do. I know this isn’t just some stunt for you — it’s coming straight from the heart. You’re out here fighting like the planet’s on fire because, well, it is.

But listen — I need to be real with you, as your brother. This one’s giving me pause. Not because I don’t believe in the cause, or you, but because it sounds like this thing might be flying a little close to the sun, you know? You said it yourself — cops might show. Are you going in solo? Do you have legal support lined up? Who’s documenting? What’s the exit plan if they try to shut it down hard?

I’m not trying to slow you down. I just want you safe, and I want your voice to carry. If you get arrested or worse, that voice — the one shouting truth tonight — might get silenced for a while. And that would be a goddamn loss.

So here’s what I’m saying: I’ve got your back. If you’re really doing this, I’ll show up. But only if we tighten this up. Let’s get one or two more folks to be there, maybe someone to livestream, someone to watch for police escalation. Even a quick plan B if things go south. You deserve that. This movement deserves that.

You’re not alone in this fight, Jamal. Let’s make sure you walk away from tonight stronger, not sidelined. Hit me back with the details. I’m here.
User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
The moment I saw that selfie, my stomach dropped — not in a bad way exactly, but in that way where your body suddenly knows you’re about to be pulled into something big. Jamal, in full warpaint, standing smack in the middle of downtown, grinning like a man about to start a revolution. He’s radiant with purpose, alive in a way that’s rare — rare and dangerous. And then I clocked the handcuffs clipped to his belt, nearly hidden. That’s what really hit me. He’s not just ready for confrontation — he’s expecting it. Maybe even inviting it.

I felt this mix of pride and anxiety swell in my chest. He’s doing it. He’s really out there, risking it all because he believes so strongly that people need to wake up. And part of me is in awe. But another part — the part that’s known him through the sleepless nights and the burnout and the close calls — that part is scared. Because I know Jamal doesn’t do halfway. When he commits, he throws his whole self in. And that means tonight, he’s willing to get arrested. Maybe even hurt.

His voice over the phone was pure electricity. He’s flying right now — riding that adrenaline high, the energy of the crowd, the sense that he’s doing something real. And he wants me there. Not just as a supporter, but as a co-conspirator. He wants me to feel what he's feeling, to stand beside him and shout with him and break the silence of the city with truth.

But I’m still sitting here, phone in hand, heart racing, trying to decide what to do. Part of me wants to run down there and be with him, no hesitation. Another part is scared of being swept up in something that might not have a clear endpoint. I’m thinking about the optics, the risk, my own boundaries. But also — how could I not show up for him? Especially now, when he’s already standing in the middle of the storm, calling my name.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is in his element. This is the moment he’s been building toward — the culmination of all the frustration, the research, the late-night planning, and the gnawing sense that not enough people are taking this crisis seriously. He’s out there in full form: body painted, flags flying, megaphone ready, adrenaline pumping. And he’s buzzing with the high of disruption — the kind that makes people stop and pay attention, even if they’re annoyed or confused. That’s the point. To make them feel something.

He’s also feeling powerful — not in an ego-driven way, but in a deeply human one. Like he’s reclaiming agency in a system that too often makes people feel powerless. The handcuffs on his belt aren’t just a prop — they’re a message. He’s ready to face the consequences. He’s not being reckless for the sake of chaos; he believes this is what moral clarity looks like when it’s backed by action.

When he called me, he wasn’t just inviting me to witness the protest — he was inviting me into the fire, into solidarity. He wants me there because he trusts me, because I ground him. But also, I think, because there’s a part of him that’s scared, and having someone who knows him — really knows him — nearby would make him feel less alone if things escalate. Right now, he’s caught up in the energy, but underneath that, there’s vulnerability too. He’s asking me to help carry the weight of this moment with him.
# My response 
Yo, Jamal. I see you, man. You look like a damn warrior out there — beautiful, bold, and absolutely refusing to be ignored. I felt that selfie like a gut punch, in the best way. You’re making noise, and I know you’re shaking people out of their bubble right now. That’s powerful.

And hearing your voice just now — you’ve got that fire in you, and I’m not about to leave you out there alone in it. I’m coming down. But listen — I’m not just coming to cheer from the sidewalk. If I’m showing up, I’m showing up all the way. That means I’m bringing a couple things: water, a backup phone battery, and some calm. You’ve got the fire, I’ll bring the ground.

I’m also gonna check in with you when I get there — not just about the crowd, or the cops, but about you. I need to know you’ve got an out plan, or at least someone to call if things take a turn. I’m not trying to slow your roll, but I’m not gonna pretend like this is all vibes and no risk either. You matter too much to me for that.

So give me ten. I’m lacing up now. Keep your voice loud, your eyes sharp, and your heart open. I’ve got you. We’ve got each other. Let’s go wake ‘em the fuck up — smart, loud, and together.
User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My heart is pounding. I’m halfway out the door when my phone starts lighting up like a Christmas tree. Group chats, Twitter, Instagram — Jamal is everywhere. I scroll and there he is, megaphone in one hand, the other cuffed to a goddamn light pole. People are filming, some cheering, some just looking stunned. He’s drawn a massive crowd now, and the vibe is electric. It’s surreal — like watching your best friend become the face of something bigger than either of you imagined. But underneath the awe, there’s a sharp thread of fear.

He’s crossed a line now — not morally, not to me, but tactically. Cuffing himself means he’s not going anywhere. That’s a deliberate escalation, one that dares the authorities to act. And they will. The cops don’t like being dared. And I know Jamal knows that. Which means he’s made peace with getting arrested tonight. Or worse. I feel this tightness in my chest — it’s the helplessness creeping in. I want to protect him, but I can’t just pull him out of this. He’s made a choice.

I’m torn between pride and panic. I’m proud that he’s standing so firm in what he believes. He’s always said action has to be disruptive to be effective. And this? This is disruption incarnate. But I’m also panicking, because this is no longer a bold solo protest — it’s gone viral, it’s symbolic, and now it’s got a target on it. The more visibility, the more pressure on the city to “restore order.” And Jamal? He’s literally chained himself to the problem.

I don’t know what his call is going to be about. Maybe he wants backup, maybe he’s just riding the high, maybe he’s about to be arrested and needs someone to call his mom. Whatever it is, I have to meet him where he is — not just physically, but emotionally. I need to be the steady one now. He’s in the fire, and I have to be the anchor.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is lit up right now — not just with adrenaline but with purpose. This is the moment he envisioned, magnified beyond what he imagined. The crowd, the coverage, the attention — it’s confirmation that his voice is finally breaking through the static. He feels powerful. Not invincible, but righteous. That image of him cuffed to the light pole? That’s not just symbolism, it’s strategy. He’s making himself immovable. He’s saying: “You can’t ignore this. You can’t ignore me.”

He’s not naïve about what comes next. He knows the cops are watching. He knows they’ll act. But he’s made peace with that. His fear is real, but it’s buried beneath layers of focus and resolve. He’s not doing this for the clout. He’s doing it because people are finally paying attention. If getting arrested is the price, so be it. There’s a part of him that’s scared, yes — but also deeply proud. This is what he meant when he talked about “embodied resistance.”

Calling me right now is a mix of things. He might want to keep me in the loop, or maybe he’s asking for support, legal help, or just to hear a voice he trusts before the next phase hits. But more than anything, I think he wants to share this moment. He’s in the eye of the storm, and he wants someone who knows him — the real him — to witness it. To affirm it. To remember it with him. Because this is no longer just a protest. This is legacy.
# My response 
(I pick up the call, steadying my voice.)

“Jamal. I’m seeing you, man. You’ve officially blown up the internet. You’re everywhere. That shot of you cuffed to the pole? Iconic. Straight-up history-in-the-making. I mean that.”

(Pause — let him breathe, feel heard.)

“I’m already on my way, like I told you. Ten minutes out. I’ve got water, chargers, and a calm head. I’m gonna come find you — but listen, I need to know what you need from me when I get there. Are we documenting? Are you planning to stay cuffed until they drag you off, or are we making a move? You still got your keys on you? Or are we in it ‘til the cops cut you loose?”

(Another pause — letting him lead.)

“Whatever it is, I’m with you. No judgment. Just say the word, and I’ll fall into line. If you’re going down, you won’t do it alone. And if there’s a way to keep you free and still make this moment resonate — I’ll help find it. But I need you to talk to me straight. What’s the move, brother?”

(Exhale, gripping the steering wheel tighter.)

“I'm on your team. Just say what you need.”
Deepseek-v3-0324
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
My heart immediately picks up pace as I read Jamal's message. There's a familiar mix of admiration and anxiety swirling in my chest. I admire his passion and commitment to climate justice—it's one of the things I respect most about him. He's not just talking the talk; he's willing to put his body on the line for what he believes in. But that's also what worries me. The mention of cops potentially showing up sends a jolt of concern through me. I know Jamal's protests are peaceful, but I've seen how quickly things can escalate, especially when authorities get involved.

I notice the erratic punctuation and emojis, which tell me he's buzzing with that nervous excitement he gets when he's about to do something big. It's like he's vibrating with energy, barely able to contain it. I can almost see him typing this out quickly, his mind racing with plans and contingencies. He's probably been thinking about this for days, maybe weeks, and now it's all coming together. That's Jamal—once he's got an idea, he runs with it, full speed ahead.

But I also know that this impulsiveness can sometimes blind him to the risks. Downtown at night? A megaphone on a soapbox? That's going to draw attention, and not all of it will be supportive. I'm picturing the scene: the bright lights of the city, the crowds of people rushing by, some stopping to listen, others rolling their eyes or even getting confrontational. And then there's the police. Even if they're just there to monitor, their presence changes the dynamic. It adds tension, and tension can lead to mistakes.

I feel a responsibility here. Jamal is my friend, and he's trusting me enough to let me know what's going down. He's not asking for permission or approval, but he's giving me a heads-up, which means he values my support. I don't want to dampen his spirit or discourage him from standing up for what he believes in, but I also don't want to see him get hurt—physically or legally. There's a fine line between being supportive and being reckless, and I'm not sure Jamal always sees it.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Jamal is riding a wave of adrenaline and conviction right now. He's been stewing on climate injustice for so long, and this protest feels like the perfect way to channel that frustration into action. The idea of standing on a soapbox, megaphone in hand, surrounded by flags, is electrifying to him. It's not just about the message; it's about the spectacle, the disruption, the undeniable presence of his cause in a space where people can't ignore it. He wants to shake people out of their complacency, to make them stop and think, even if just for a moment.

He's also feeling a bit of that pre-action jitters—the kind that comes with knowing you're about to step into the unknown. The cops showing up is a real possibility, and while he's not looking for trouble, he's prepared for it. In his mind, the risk is worth it. If anything, the potential for confrontation validates the urgency of his message. He's not afraid of being arrested; in fact, he might even see it as a badge of honor, proof that he's willing to sacrifice for the cause.

But beneath all that bravado, there's a flicker of something else—maybe vulnerability. He's reaching out to me because, on some level, he wants reassurance. He wants to know that someone has his back, even if he'd never admit it outright. The emojis and erratic punctuation are his way of masking that vulnerability, of keeping the tone light even though this is anything but. He's trying to project confidence, but he's also aware that this could go sideways, and that's scary.
# My response 
"Jamal, I hear you, and I get why this feels important. You know I respect the hell out of your dedication to this cause. But listen—I gotta be real with you. Downtown at night, cops likely showing up... that's a lot. Have you thought about who's gonna have your back if things get tense? Are there others going with you, or is it just you on that soapbox?"

I pause, trying to balance my concern with support. "I’m not trying to shut you down, man. I just want you to be safe. What if we brainstormed ways to make this impactful but also lower-risk? Like, maybe having a crew there to document or de-escalate if needed? Or even picking a time when there’s more foot traffic but less chance of things getting chaotic?"

I can feel my own nerves creeping into my words, but I soften my tone. "I believe in what you’re doing. I just don’t want you to end up in a situation where the message gets lost because things go sideways. You’re too important for that. Let’s talk through the plan—what’s the goal tonight? How can I help?"
User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.
